A freight train is a group of freight cars (US) or goods wagons (UIC) hauled by one or more locomotives on a railway, ultimately transporting cargo between a shipper and a receiver.

A freight train is a group of freight cars (US) or goods wagons (UIC) hauled by one or more locomotives on a railway, ultimately transporting cargo between a shipper and a receiver. Similarly, a train may consist entirely of passenger carrying coaches, some or all of which are powered as a "multiple unit".

A freight train is a group of freight cars (US) or goods wagons (UIC) hauled by one or more locomotives on a railway, ultimately transporting cargo between two points as part of the logistics chain. Trains may haul bulk material, intermodal containers, general freight or specialized freight in purpose-designed cars.

A train is a form of rail transport consisting of a series of connected vehicles that generally run along a railroad track to transport cargo or passengers.
Freight trains transport goods, raw materials and products, such as coal, grain, steel, automobiles and consumer goods, between cities and towns.

The term freight train is used by the International Union of Railways (UIC), while the term goods train is used in Great Britain.
A passenger train or passenger rail service is a form of rail transport that carries passengers.
A passenger train is one which includes passenger-carrying vehicles which can often be very long and fast.
Freight trains do not carry passengers.
